CHAPTER 149
Planning and Zoning Commission
149.01   Appointment; compensation; terms.
149.02   Duties.
149.03   Organization and rules.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Establishing a Planning Commission - see Ohio R.C. 713.01
Planning Commission powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 713.02, 713.06
Planning Commission shall be Platting Commission - see Ohio R.C. 713.03
Zoning and subdivision fees - see P. & Z. Ch.
1101
Review of zoning amendments - see P. & Z. Ch.
1119
 
149.01 APPOINTMENT; COMPENSATION; TERMS.
   (a) The Planning Commission shall consist of the Mayor, one member of
Council and three residents of the Municipality appointed by the Mayor.
   (b) The member of Council so serving, shall be elected by the remaining
members of Council and his term shall coincide with the term for which he is
elected to Council.
   (c)   The terms of the resident appointees shall be for four years.
   (d)   All such members shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
149.02 DUTIES.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall
have the following duties:
   (a)   Review all proposed amendments to the Zoning Ordinance and make
recommendations to Council.
   (b)   Review all planned unit developments and mobile home park proposals
and make recommendations to the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (c)   Carry out all responsibilities assigned to it by Council or by the
Zoning Ordinance of the Municipality.
      (Ord. 1972-57. Passed 1-15-73.)
149.03 ORGANIZATION AND RULES.
   (a)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall organize annually and elect a
chairman, vice-chairman and secretary from its membership. The secretary need
not be a member of the Planning Commission. The Commission shall adopt rules as
may be necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this chapter and to
exercise the powers and jurisdiction conferred upon it by this chapter, the
Zoning Code of the Municipality and the laws of the State.
 
   (b)   The chairman shall preside at the meetings of the Commission. He shall
decide on all points of order and procedure, unless otherwise directed by a
majority of this Commission. The chairman may appoint committees deemed
necessary to carry out the business of the Commission. The chairman may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. The chairman's
signature shall be the official signature of the Commission and shall appear on
all decisions as directed by the Commission.
 
   (c)   The vice-chairman shall serve in the absence of the chairman. He shall
have all of the powers of the chairman during his absence, disability or
disqualification.
 
   (d)   The secretary shall keep minutes of all meetings and shall be
responsible for all official correspondence of the Commission.
      (1)   Meetings. Meetings of the Commission shall be held at the call of
the chairman and such other times as the Commission may determine. All meetings
shall be open to the public.
         All actions of the Commission shall be taken by resolution, the vote
of each member recorded. The majority of the Commission shall constitute a
quorum to do business.
         No member of the Planning Commission shall vote on any matter in which
he is personally or financially interested.
          (Ord. 1972-57. Passed 1-15-73.)
      (2)   Minutes and records. The secretary of the Commission shall keep
minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question,
or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact and shall keep records of
its examinations and other official action, all of which shall be certified
correct and filed in the Clerk of Council's office and shall be a public
record. (Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
 
CHAPTER 151
Shade Tree Commission
151.01   Establishment; membership.
151.02   Term of office.
151.03   Members not compensated.
151.04   Powers and duties; organization; quorum.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Destruction of shrubs and trees - see GEN. OFF.
541.06
Cutting, removing and planting trees - see S.U. & P.S.
913.01
 
151.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby created and established a Shade Tree Commission in the
Municipality which shall consist of the following five members: the Chairman of
the Public Works Committee of Council; the Village Manager; and three persons
who are residents of the Municipality who shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the advice and consent of Council.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 6-4-01; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
151.02 TERM OF OFFICE.
   Official members of the Shade Tree Commission shall serve coincidental with
their official terms of office and the three appointed members shall serve for
a term of four years each beginning July 1, 1970, except that the term of three
of the members first appointed shall be for one, two and three years,
respectively. Each year, beginning July 1, 1971, one member shall be appointed
for a term of four years. If a vacancy occurs during the term of any member,
his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 6-4-01.)
151.03 MEMBERS NOT COMPENSATED.
   Members of the Shade Tree Commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 6-4-01.)
151.04 POWERS AND DUTIES; ORGANIZATION; QUORUM.
   (a)   The Shade Tree Commission shall have the power to study, investigate,
plan, advise, report and recommend to Council, the Chairman of the Public Works
Committee or the Mayor, any action, program, plan or legislation which the
Commission finds or determines to be necessary or advisable for the care,
preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal or other disposition of
trees and shrubs in public ways, streets, alleys and parks of the Municipality.
   (b)   The Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and
regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members
shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. All plans, findings,
reports and recommendations made by the Commission shall be in writing and
shall designate by name those members of the Commission approving or concurring
therein. Members who do not approve or concur in the report submitted shall
have the right, as part of such report, to state their reasons for refusing to
approve or concur.
   (c)   The Commission, when requested by Council, the Mayor or the Chairman
of the Public Works Committee, shall consider, investigate, make findings,
report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the
scope of its work.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 6-4-01.)
CHAPTER 154
Coordinator of Services for Seniors
154.01   Position established.
 
154.01 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established the office of Coordinator of
Services for Seniors.
 
   (b)   The duties and responsibilities of any person or persons named to the
Office of Coordinator of Services for Seniors shall be to plan, coordinate and
implement programs, activities and services to assist the aging and the elderly
to better enable them to enjoy those years remaining to them; to provide such
counsel, advice and referral service as may be appropriate in order to assist
the aging and the elderly to receive proper and safe housing, transportation,
care and treatment along with the benefits and services of other social and
service agencies in the County, State and Nation.
 
   (c)   The Coordinator(s) of Services for Seniors shall be appointed annually
in January of each year by the Mayor with the approval of a majority of Council
and shall serve a term of one year or until a successor is appointed. In the
event of a vacancy in the office at any time, the appointment shall be in like
manner for the unexpired term thereof. Compensation shall be as determined by
Council. The Coordinator shall be responsible to Council and shall provide such
reports and data as Council shall deem necessary to enable it to carry out its
function.
 
   (d)   There is hereby created a Senior Advisory Board consisting of seven
members. The Board shall consist of the Mayor and two members of Council whose
terms on the Board shall coincide with the terms of their respective elected
offices. The remainder of the Senior Advisory Board shall consist of four area
residents aged fifty-five or older who shall be appointed annually in January
of each year by the Mayor with the approval of a majority of Council. Members
of the Board shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for
personal expenses incurred, if any. In the event of any vacancy on the Board
the same shall be filled in like manner for the remainder of the unexpired
term.
 
   (e)   The Senior Advisory Board shall be charged with the responsibility of
general oversight and direction over the operations of the office of the
Coordinator of Services for Seniors and shall, from time to time as requested,
and at least once annually, present to Council a complete report of the
activities and operations of such office.
 
   (f)   The Senior Advisory Board shall meet at least quarterly and a majority
of the Board present shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any
business required.
(Ord. 1984-18. Passed 9-5-84.)
CHAPTER 155
Board of Cemetery Supervisors
155.01   Appointment; compensation.
155.02   Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Burials may be prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 759.05
Management and control - see Ohio R.C. 759.20
 
155.01 APPOINTMENT; COMPENSATION.
   A joint session of Council and Township Trustees shall be held at the first
regular meeting of Council in May of each year, when there shall be appointed
one member of the Board of Cemetery Supervisors for a term of three years
beginning on the first of each January following such appointment and until his
successor is appointed and qualified. The Board shall consist of three members,
at least one of whom shall be a Councilman of the Municipality and at least one
of whom shall be a Trustee of Wellington Township.
   The Board of Cemetery Supervisors may fix the compensation of the members
thereof, and such compensation shall be in accordance with the time actually
consumed by such members in the discharge of their official duties, but shall
not exceed the amount provided in Ohio R.C. 759.31.
(Ord. 1691. Passed 7-21-58.)
155.02 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Board of Cemetery Supervisors shall be to inspect and
supervise all improvements made in the cemeteries and to recommend to Council
and the Township Trustees any and all improvements which in its judgment are
necessary. The Board shall adopt all plans for the improvement of the same, but
if such plans will require an expenditure of over the amount specified in Ohio
R.C. 731.14 at any one time, it shall, before adoption submit such plans to
Council and the Township Trustees for their approval. The Board shall advise
the Sexton and make known to him all plans for any improvement adopted by the
Board or by Council and the Township Trustees, and see that those plans are
duly carried out. The Board shall also have general supervision and control
over cemeteries, subject to the approval of Council.
(Ord. 1203. Passed 6-3-46.)
CHAPTER 157
Treasury Investment Board
157.01   Treasury investment.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Clerk-Treasurer - see ADM. Ch.
133
 
157.01 TREASURY INVESTMENT.
   (a)   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the Village which will
not be required to be used by the Village for a period of six months or more,
such moneys may in lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in
obligations of the Village or in such other bonds or obligations as are or may
be specified in Ohio R.C. Section 731.56, now in effect or as the same may from
time to time be hereafter amended.
 
   (b)   Such investments shall be made in the manner pursuant to the terms and
provisions set forth in Ohio R.C. 731.56 to 731.59.
(Ord. 1973-5. Passed 1-15-73.)
 
 
CHAPTER 158
Town Hall Manager

158.01 POSITION ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   There is hereby created a position to be known as Town Hall Manager whose
duty it shall be to assist the Village Manager in scheduling the use of
Village-maintained facilities for such purposes as shall, from time to time be
directed by the Village Manager or by Council; to collect and account for all
admission, rental and other receipts derived from the use of such facilities
and to maintain or cause such facilities to be maintained in a neat, orderly
condition.
(Ord. 1982-14. Passed 3-15-82; Ord. 1993-20. Passed 6-21-93; Ord. 1993-32.
Passed 11-1-93; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
CHAPTER 159
Employment Provisions
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 2004-10, passed on April 5, 2004, adopted a
personnel policy manual for the Municipality. The Clerk-Treasurer has copies of
the manual on file in the Municipal Building.

159.01 BONDS.
   The following persons shall be required to furnish a good and sufficient
bond, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of their
positions, in the respective amount set forth herein. The premium payable on
any such bond shall be paid by the Municipality.
 
(a) Mayor                                                 $1,000
(b) Director of Finance                                   5,000
(c) Police Chief and each member of the Police Department
                                                          1,000
(d) Deputy Director of Finance                            10,000
    (Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
159.02 LONGEVITY COMPENSATION.
   (a)   In order to compensate Municipal employees who have been so employed
for extended periods of time, there shall be computed and paid to each
qualifying employee of this Municipality a percentage of that employee's base
rate of pay according to the table set forth in this section and which follows
the employee's qualifications hereunder.
   (b)   An employee shall be deemed to be qualified for additional
compensation under this section when the employee has completed the specified
number of years of regular and continuous employment by this Municipality as
set forth herein. An interruption of service or leave of absence in excess of
sixty days except for military service, shall be determined to be a termination
and the beginning of a new term of employment under this section. Years of
regular and continuous service prior to the effective date of this section
shall be counted for purposes of this section for all those presently employed.
   (c)   Additional compensation to be paid shall be computed as follows:
 
Years Employed                 Additional
After completion of five years 2%
ten years                      4%
fifteen years                  6%
(Ord. 1973-78. Passed 1-21-74.)
159.03 COMPENSATION FOR COURT APPEARANCE.
   Police officers who are required to attend court while off duty shall be
paid the sum of either one hundred dollars ($100.00) or the officer’s pay at
his regular rate (plus any applicable overtime premium), whichever would be
greater, for each appearance.
(Ord. 2005-56. Passed 12-5-05.)
159.04 POLICE UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   In order to maintain a neat appearance, it is necessary that an
allowance be made for members of the Police Department, including full-time and
part-time officers and dispatchers, to allow for the purchase of those required
uniforms.
   (b)    A uniform allowance shall be available annually beginning from and
after June 21, 2022 as follows:
 
      Full-time Officers           $1,100.00
      Part-time Officers           $750.00
      Full-time Dispatchers           $450.00
      Part-time Dispatchers           $300.00
   During October of each year, purchases of authorized equipment may be made
through the Village at the request of Police Department members in amounts not
to exceed the stated allowances. Any amount of the allowance not so spent shall
not be redeemed in cash, nor carried over from one year to the next.
   (c)   In the event a uniform or personal required equipment such as
prescription glasses, watches or shoes is damaged or destroyed while the
officer is on duty, the Village shall repair or replace the uniform or
equipment as necessary and may seek restitution from the offending party
through legal process.
   (d)   When a newly employed full-time or part-time Police Officer or
dispatcher is hired, he/she shall be outfitted with the required uniform and
equipment to perform their duties as approved by the Chief of Police.
Acquisition of such uniform and equipment will be the responsibility of the
employee; but the Village shall loan the cost of the same to the employee,
subject to later forgiveness if the employee completes one year of service to
the Village. The uniform allowance provided for herein shall be available after
the first anniversary of the date of hire. (Ord. 2022-24. Passed 6-21-22; Ord.
2022-36. Passed 9-19-22.)
159.05 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES GENERALLY.
   (a)   For all employees not subject to Section
159.04 of the Codified Ordinances, a uniform allowance shall be available
annually, beginning in 2018, as follows:
      Full-time employees         $450.00
      Permanent part-time employees   $225.00
   (b)   When, in the opinion of the Village Manager, the work being performed
by an employee requires the use of special protective clothing, the
Municipality shall furnish and pay for such items as may be necessary.
   (c)   When a newly employed member of the Auxiliary Police is hired, he
shall not be subject to the provisions for police uniform allowance set forth
in Section
159.05; but he/she shall be outfitted with the required uniform and equipment
to perform their duties as approved by the Chief of Police. Thereafter, after
the first anniversary of the date of hire, he/she shall be entitled to the
benefit applicable to a part-time employee under subsection (a), above.
(Ord. 2022-52. Passed 12-5-22.)
159.06 REIMBURSEMENT FOR USE OF PERSONAL VEHICLE.
   (a)   The Chief of Police shall receive, in addition to salary payments
provided by other ordinance, the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per
calendar year as agreed upon compensation for the use of his own personal
transportation for attendance at various official functions and meetings held
outside the Municipality but required of him as Chief to attend.
   (b)   Payment of the earned portion of such sums shall be made at the end of
each calendar quarter of his employment, namely, March 31, June 30 and
September 30 and December 31 in each year with prorated adjustment for any
period less than one full quarter year.
(Ord. 1983-29. Passed 6-6-83.)
159.07  COST OF LIVING ADJUSTMENT.
   (a)   Annually in April of each year beginning 2004 and continuing through
April 2013 on the same basis, the Director of Finance shall determine the
amount of increase or decrease in the Cost of Living Index over the preceding
12 month period as announced by the United States Department of Labor, shall
report the same to Council, and shall make appropriate corresponding changes in
the compensation to be paid Village employees for the next succeeding twelve
months.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
   (b)   The percentage of change in the Cost of Living Index shall only be
applied to the Base Rate of Pay as set forth in the table above and not to any
employee’s current rate of pay computed as the result of the application of
prior Cost of Living Adjustments so as to avoid compounding of increases or
decreases.
   (c)   Should the change in the Cost of Living Index exceed 5% in any 12
month period affecting these employees, only the first 5% change shall be
applied in full to the Base Rate of Pay with half (50%) of the next 5% of
change to be applied. Should the change in the Cost of Living Index exceed 10%
in any period of measurement only one-fourth (25%) of any excess over 10% shall
be applied.
   (d)   In the year 2013 new Base Rates of compensation shall be established
in each of the categories stated herein which Base Rates shall be the
equivalent of the existing rate of compensation for each step as adjusted from
time to time by the application of percent changes in Cost of Living Index
Changes after completion of eight (8) years under this ordinance. Thereafter on
each tenth anniversary of this enactment similar adjustments in the Base Rates
of Compensation shall be made with the adjusted Base Rate reflecting in each
case the current rate of pay in each category as it existed two years prior to
such anniversary date.
 
   (e)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary as set forth hereinabove, in
any year, the Cost of Living Adjustment shall be adjusted or eliminated if the
Council, by majority vote, declares, prior to the first regular pay date in
April of that year, that any Cost of Living increase which would normally be
awarded for that year shall either be eliminated or reduced, as Council may
designate, for that year.
 
   (f)   Nothing in the foregoing provisions shall be construed to restrain or
restrict the authority of any future Council to alter, amend, or repeal the
structure of Cost of Living pay increases provided herein.
(Ord. 2004-09. Passed 4-5-04.)
 
159.08  REEMPLOYMENT OF RETIREES.
   Notwithstanding any other ordinance or any provision of the Village’s
Employee Handbook to the contrary:
   (a)   Any individual who retires from employment with the Village of
Wellington shall, to the extent otherwise permitted by State law, be eligible
for appointment to any position within the Village of Wellington along with any
other member of the public at large.
   (b)   An individual who retires from employment with the Village of
Wellington shall not, by that fact alone, be entitled to any preference by the
appointing authority in consideration of applicants for any position. If an
individual applies for appointment to the same position from which he retired,
that fact shall not prevent the appointing authority from accepting
applications from the public at large; however, the appointing authority may
consider that individual’s prior experience in determining the best qualified
candidate for a position.
   (c)   Except to the extent specifically required by State law, an individual
who retires from the Village of Wellington and is subsequently hired by the
Village shall be considered as a “new hire,” and shall be eligible for pay
rates and benefits that would accrue to any other new hire, without
consideration for prior years service.
      (Ord. 2006-40. Passed 10-2-06.)

161.01 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Zoning Inspector for the
Municipality. Said Zoning Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
approval of the majority of Council. The Zoning Inspector shall be available
for regular office hours as established by Council and shall attend all
Planning Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals meetings and perform such
duties as are consistent with the municipal Zoning Ordinance and such other
duties as may be designated by the Planning Commission with the approval of
Council.
   (b)   The Mayor, with the approval of the Council, may appoint one or more,
full-time or part-time Assistant Zoning Inspectors. Such duly appointed
employees shall have the same lawful authority as the Zoning Inspector and may
act or enforce ordinances to the same extent as the Zoning Inspector. (Ord.
2008-58. Passed 2-2-09.)
CHAPTER 165
Personal Information Systems
165.01   Definitions.
165.02   Identification of personal information systems.
165.03   Creation or substantial enlargement of personal information systems.
165.04   Appointment of individuals responsible for systems.
165.05   Establishment of rules.
165.06   Distribution of statutory provisions and rules.
165.07   Annual review of personal information systems.
165.08   Duties in the operation of personal information systems.
165.09   Use of personal information.
165.10   Prohibition against retaliatory actions.
165.11   Rights of inspection.
165.12   Disputes concerning information in a system.
165.13   Right of action for harm done.
165.14   Exemptions.
165.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Employees generally - see ADM. Ch.
159
165.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Personal information" means any information that describes anything
about a person, or that indicates actions done by or to a person, or that
indicates that a person possesses certain personal characteristics, and that
contains, and can be retrieved from a system by, a name, identifying number,
symbol or other identifier assigned to a person.
   (b)   "System" means any collection or group of related records that are
kept in an organized manner and from which personal information is retrieved by
the name of the person or by some identifying number, symbol or other
identifier assigned to the person. "System" includes both records that are
manually stored and records that are stored using electronic data processing
equipment. "System" does not include published directories, reference materials
or newsletters, or routine information that is maintained for the purpose of
internal office administration, the use of which would not adversely affect a
person.
   (c)   "Maintains" means ownership of, control over, responsibility for, or
accountability for systems, and includes depositing information with a data
processing center for storage, processing or dissemination.
   (d)   "Village Official" means, for purposes of this Chapter, the Mayor,
Clerk-Treasurer/Finance Director, the Manager, and any commission or board of
the Village government.
   (e)   "Personal Information System Officer" means an individual who has been
appointed pursuant to Section
165.04.
      (Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.02 IDENTIFICATION OF PERSONAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS.
   Every Village Official shall annually survey all records which are
maintained in his office and identify those records which constitute a personal
information system. On or before November 1 of each year, a report of the
Personal Information Systems he has identified shall be completed for each
system identified and shall be forwarded to the office of the Mayor.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.03 CREATION OR SUBSTANTIAL ENLARGEMENT OF PERSONAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS.
   Whenever a Village Official establishes a new personal information system or
substantially enlarges a prior existing one, he shall complete documentation of
that Personal Information System and forward it to the office of the Mayor.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.04 APPOINTMENT OF INDIVIDUALS RESPONSIBLE FOR SYSTEMS.
   (a)   Each Village Official shall identify all presently existing personal
information systems; and, upon reviewing the day-to-day operation of each
system, he shall appoint one individual, which may be himself, who will be
directly responsible for each system, and who will be known as a Personal
Information System Officer.
   (b)   When an individual appointed under subsection (a) hereof leaves the
employment of the Village or is absent for any reason for an extended period of
time, the supervising Village Official shall appoint a replacement.
   (c)   Whenever a personal information system is created, the supervising
Village Official shall appoint an appropriate person to be directly responsible
for the new system.
   (d)   Whenever an appointment is made pursuant to this section, the name of
the appointee shall be submitted to the office of the Mayor, where a record of
all such appointees shall be kept. (Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.05 ESTABLISHMENT OF RULES.
   The enactment of this Chapter constitutes the adoption of Rules for the
operation of personal information systems. All officers and employees shall
operate and use personal information systems in accordance with the provisions
of this Chapter.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.06 DISTRIBUTION OF STATUTORY PROVISIONS AND RULES.
   A written copy of Ohio Revised Code Chapter 1347 and of this Chapter of the
Codified Ordinances shall be distributed to each employee dealing with a
personal information system, and a copy shall at all times be kept in the
office where the records are maintained. Any officer of employee of the Village
who acts in violation of this Chapter shall be subject to disciplinary action.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.07 ANNUAL REVIEW OF PERSONAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS.
   On or before November 1 of each year, each Village Official shall confer
with the Personal Information System Officers under his supervision and take
the following actions:
   (a)   Eliminate personal information from the information system which is no
longer timely;
   (b)   Determine whether all personal information maintained is necessary and
relevant to the functions that his office is required or authorized by law to
perform. In the event it is found that information is being maintained which is
not legally required or authorized, the Village Official shall:
      (1)   Eliminate that information from the system, in compliance with the
requirements of State law; or
      (2)   Propose legislation to the Mayor which would authorize or require
such information to be kept.
         (Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.08 DUTIES IN THE OPERATION OF PERSONAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS.
   Every Personal Information System Officer shall:
   (a)   Inform a person asked to supply information for a system whether he is
legally required to supply such information;
   (b)   Maintain personal information in the system with such accuracy,
relevance, timeliness and completeness as is necessary to assure fairness in
any determination made with respect to the person on the basis of the
information;
   (c)   Take reasonable precautions to protect personal information in the
system from any anticipated threat or hazard to the security of the system; and
   (d)   Collect only personal information that is necessary and relevant to
the functions that he is required or authorized by law to perform.
      (Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.09 USE OF PERSONAL INFORMATION.
   Personal information shall only be used in a manner that is consistent with
the lawful purposes of the personal information system from which it comes.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.10 PROHIBITION AGAINST RETALIATORY ACTIONS.
   No Village employee shall initiate or otherwise contribute to any
disciplinary or other punitive action against any individual who brings to the
attention of appropriate authorities, the press or any other member of the
public, evidence of unauthorized use of personal information contained in the
system. (Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.11 RIGHTS OF INSPECTION.
   (a)   Every Personal Information System Officer shall, upon the request of
any properly identified person:
      (1)   Inform the person of the existence of any personal information in
the system of which he is the subject;
      (2)   Except as provided in subsection (c) hereof, permit the person, his
legal guardian, or an attorney who presents a signed written authorization made
by the person, to inspect all personal information in the system of which he is
the subject; and
      (3)   Inform the person about the types of uses made of any such personal
information, including the identity of any users usually granted access to the
system.
   (b)   Any person who wishes to exercise a right provided for by this section
may be accompanied by another individual of his choice.
   (c)   Every Personal Information System Officer, upon request, shall
disclose medical, psychiatric or psychological information to a person who is
the subject of the information or to his legal guardian unless a physician,
psychiatrist or psychologist determines for the agency that the disclosure of
the information is likely to have an adverse effect on the person in which case
the information shall be released to a physician, psychiatrist or psychologist
designated by the person or by his legal guardian.
   (d)   Upon the payment of a fee of twenty-five cents (25¢) per page, the
Personal Information System Officer shall supply a copy of personal information
regarding a particular individual to any person who would be entitled to
inspect the information pursuant to this section.
   (e)   This section does not provide a person who is the subject of personal
information maintained in a personal information system, his or her legal
guardian or an attorney authorized by the person, with a right to inspect or
have copied, or require an agency that maintains a personal information system
to permit the inspection of or to copy, a confidential law enforcement
investigatory record or trial preparation record.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.12 DISPUTES CONCERNING INFORMATION IN A SYSTEM.
   (a)   If any person disputes the accuracy, relevance, timeliness or
completeness of the personal information pertaining to him that is maintained
in any personal information system, he may request the Personal Information
System Officer to investigate the current status of the information. Within a
reasonable time thereafter and following a reasonable, diligent investigation,
the disputant shall be notified of the results of the investigation and the
nature of any corrective action which will be taken. The information retained
in the system must be in compliance with Section
165.08(b), and any inaccurate or unverifiable information must be deleted.
   (b)   If a disputant is not satisfied with the result of actions taken under
subsection (a) hereof, the Personal Information System Officer shall assist the
disputant in preparing:
      (1)   A statement of 100 words or less which explains the basis for his
dispute and which will be included in any subsequent transfer, report of
dissemination of the information; or
      (2)   A notation of 100 words or less which states that the disputant
protests against the use of the information for being inaccurate, irrelevant,
outdated or incomplete and which will be included in any subsequent transfer,
report or dissemination of the information.
   (c)   Whenever a statement is filed pursuant to subsection (b) hereof, the
Personal Information System Officer shall prepare a brief statement to be
included in all dissemination of the disputed information which states that the
dispute is considered frivolous or irrelevant and states the basis for that
opinion. The presence of contradictory information in the file is not alone a
sufficient basis for considering the dispute frivolous or irrelevant.
   (d)   Whenever information is deleted or disputed, pursuant to subsections
(a) and (b) hereof, the Personal Information System Officer shall, at the
written request of the disputant, furnish notification of the deletion or a
copy of the disputant's statement to any person specifically designated by the
disputant. Whenever a dispute arises under this section, the disputant shall be
notified in writing that he has the right to request the notification provided
by this paragraph.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.13 RIGHT OF ACTION FOR HARM DONE.
   Any person harmed by the use or disclosure of information in violation of
any provision of this chapter shall have such rights of action for damages as
may be established by State law.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)
165.14 EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   The provisions of this Chapter shall have no application to the
records and procedures of the Division of Police or the Village Prosecutor.
   (b)   Nothing in this Chapter shall be interpreted to conflict with State of
Ohio statutes concerning the disclosure of public records, to the extent the
same may directly conflict with the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 2012-02.
Passed 3-7-12.)
165.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever maintains, or is employed by a person who maintains, a
personal information system, and purposely refuses to comply with or violates
any of the provisions of Section
165.07,
165.08,
165.09,
165.10,
165.11(a), (b) or (c) or
165.12 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (b)   An officer of employee of the Village who complies in good faith with
the provisions of this Chapter is not subject to criminal liability.
(Ord. 2012-02. Passed 3-7-12.)

CHAPTER 181
Income Tax
181.01   Definitions.
