553.01 OBSTRUCTING STREETS BY RAILROAD COMPANIES.
   (a)   (1)   No railroad company shall obstruct or permit or cause to be
obstructed a public street, road or highway by permitting a railroad car,
locomotive or other obstruction to remain upon or across it for longer than
five minutes to the hindrance or inconvenience of travelers or a person passing
along or upon such street, road or highway.
      (2)   At the end of each five minute period of obstruction of a public
street, road or highway, each railroad company shall cause such railroad car,
locomotive or other obstruction to be removed for sufficient time, not less
than three minutes, to allow the passage of persons and vehicles waiting to
cross.
      (3)   This section does not apply to obstruction of a public street, road
or highway by a continuously moving through train or caused by circumstances
wholly beyond the control of the railroad company, but does apply to other
obstructions, including without limitation those caused by stopped trains and
trains engaged in switching, loading or unloading operations.
      (4)   If a railroad car, locomotive, or other obstruction is obstructing
a public street, road, or highway in violation of subsection (a)(1) hereof and
the violation occurs in the unincorporated area of one or more counties, or in
one or more municipal corporations, the officers and employees of each affected
county or municipal corporation may charge the railroad company with only one
violation of the law arising from the same facts and circumstances and the same
act.
      (5)   Upon the filing of an affidavit or complaint for violation of this
subsection (a)(1) hereof, summons shall be issued to the railroad company
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2935.10(B), which summons shall be served on the regular
ticket or freight agent of the company in the county where the offense
occurred.
(ORC 5589.21)
   (b)   For purposes of this section, "railroad company" includes the
officers, employees and agents of such company.
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree and shall be fined one thousand dollars ($1,000).
553.011 OBSTRUCTING STREETS BY ABANDONING THE LOCOMOTIVE.
   (a)   No railroad company shall obstruct, or permit or cause to be
obstructed, a public street, road, or highway, by permitting any part of a
train whose crew has abandoned the locomotive to remain across it for longer
than five minutes to the hindrance or inconvenience of travelers or a person
passing along or upon the street, road, or highway, unless the safety of the
train crew requires them to abandon the locomotive.
   (b)   Upon the filing of an affidavit or complaint for violation of this
section, summons shall be issued to the railroad company pursuant to Ohio R.C.
2935.10(B), which summons shall be served on the regular ticket or freight
agent of the company in the county where the offense occurred.
(ORC 5589.211)
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree and shall be fined five thousand dollars ($5,000).
(ORC 5589.99)
553.02 CLIMBING UPON RAILROAD CARS.
   (a)   No person shall climb, jump, step or stand upon or cling or attach
himself to a locomotive, engine or car upon the track of a railroad, unless in
compliance with law or by permission under the rules of the corporation
managing such railroad.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(ORC 4999.02)
553.03 DUTIES OF LOCOMOTIVE ENGINEER.
   (a)   No person in charge of a locomotive shall fail to bring the locomotive
to a full stop at least 200 feet before arriving at a crossing with another
track, or proceed through the crossing before signaled to do so or before the
way is clear.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree. If violation of this misdemeanor causes physical harm to any person,
whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(ORC 4999.04)
553.04 RAILROAD VANDALISM.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly, and by any means, drop or throw any object
at, onto, or in the path of, any railroad rail, railroad track, locomotive,
engine, railroad car, or other vehicle of a railroad company while such vehicle
is on a railroad track.
   (b)   No person, without privilege to do so, shall climb upon or into any
locomotive, engine, railroad car, or other vehicle of a railroad company when
it is on a railroad track.
   (c)   No person, without privilege to do so, shall disrupt, delay, or
prevent the operation of any train or other vehicle of a railroad company while
such vehicle is on a railroad track.
   (d)   Whoever violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of railroad
vandalism. Whoever violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of
criminal trespass on a locomotive, engine, railroad car or other railroad
vehicle. Whoever violates subsection (c) of this section is guilty of
interference with the operation of a train.
   Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, railroad vandalism;
criminal trespass on a locomotive, engine, railroad car, or other railroad
vehicle; and interference with the operation of a train each is a misdemeanor
of the first degree. If the violation of subsection (a), (b) or (c) of this
section causes serious physical harm to property, creates a substantial risk of
physical harm to any person, causes physical harm to any person, or serious
physical harm to any person, the violation is a felony and shall be prosecuted
under appropriate State law.
   (e)   No person shall knowingly deface, damage, obstruct, remove, or
otherwise impair the operation of any railroad grade crossing warning signal or
other protective device, including any gate, bell, light, crossbuck, stop sign,
yield sign, advance warning sign, or advance pavement
marking.
   (f)   Whoever violates subsection (e) of this section is guilty of railroad
grade crossing device vandalism. Except as otherwise provided in this division,
railroad grade crossing device vandalism is a misdemeanor of the first degree.
If the violation of subsection (e) of this section causes serious physical harm
to property or creates a substantial risk of physical harm to any person,
causes physical harm to any person, or causes serious physical harm to any
person, railroad grade crossing device vandalism is a felony to be prosecuted
under appropriate state law.
(ORC 2909.10, 2909.101)
553.05 GRADE CROSSING DEVICE VANDALISM.
   (a)   No person shall knowingly deface, damage, obstruct, remove or
otherwise impair the operation of any railroad grade crossing warning signal or
other protective device, including any gate, bell, light, crossbuck, stop sign,
yield sign, advance warning sign, or advance pavement marking.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of railroad grade crossing
device vandalism. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, railroad
grade crossing device vandalism is a misdemeanor of the first degree. If the
violation of this section causes serious physical harm to property, creates a
substantial risk of physical harm to any person, causes physical harm to any
person, or causes serious physical harm to any person, railroad grade crossing
device vandalism is a felony and shall be prosecuted under appropriate State
law.
(ORC 2909.101)
553.06 QUIET ZONE.
   (a)   Council does hereby establish, authorize, and direct the creation of a
Railroad Quiet Zone within the Village, in accordance with specifications on
file with the Village Manager.
 
   (b)   The Mayor and Village Manager be, and hereby they are, authorized and
directed to cause a Notice of Intent to be issued in accordance with federal
and state laws to the Federal Rail Administration, the Ohio Department of
Transportation, the Public Utilities Commission, and CSX, requesting formal
comments to the proposed Quiet Zone, to enable the Village to thereafter
proceed with cost estimates and implementation plans therefor.
(Ord. 2016-14. Passed 4-18-16.)
553.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
501.99 for penalties applicable to any misdemeanor classification.)

CHAPTER 729
Peddlers and Canvassers
729.01   Peddlers.
729.02   Canvassers.
729.03   Appeals.
729.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
 
729.01  PEDDLERS.
   (a)   “Peddler,” as used in this chapter, means any person who is at least
eighteen years of age, who goes from house to house or from place to place
through the streets of the Village of Wellington, and who:
      (1)   Carries with him for the purpose of sale at retail and immediate or
future delivery goods, wares, food or merchandise; or
      (2)   For himself, or as principal or agent for another, sells offers to
sell, or otherwise obtains orders or commitments for the sale, repair, or
exchange of goods, wares, food, merchandise, or services.
   Notwithstanding the foregoing, a person is not acting as a peddler under any
of the following circumstances:
      (1)   He is responding to a prior request from the person being
contacted;
      (2)   He is contacting only members of the same entity, group, or
organization on whose behalf he is peddling;
      (3)   He is making a delivery of goods, wares, food, or merchandise which
has previously been ordered;
      (4)   He is engaged in commercial sales to a commercial business on
behalf of a manufacturer, wholesaler, distributor, or other supplier; or
      (5)   He is engaged solely in canvassing.
   (b)   No person shall either engage in business as a peddler or, as the
employee of another for such purpose, act as a peddler within the Village of
Wellington, without having obtained a license issued by the Village Chief of
Police or his designee.
   (c)   Application for a license to act as a peddler shall be filed with the
Village Chief of Police by the individual requesting license as a peddler or by
the seller he represents, on a form to be furnished by the Chief of Police,
which shall require the following information:
      (1)   Name of the applicant;
      (2)   If the applicant is an individual, a physical description of the
individual;
      (3)   The applicant’s Social Security number or federal identification
number;
      (4)   The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is
employed or for whom he is peddling, if any, and the length of the applicant’s
service for that employer;
      (5)   The name(s) and address(es) of all the persons who will be peddling
pursuant to this license;
      (6)   The nature and character of the goods to be sold or services to be
furnished by the peddler;
      (7)   A statement as to whether any individual to be covered by the
license has ever been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude, including the date and place of conviction; and
      (8)   Two copies of a current photograph, approximately 2" x 2", of each
individual to be covered by the application.
   (d)   The Chief of Police shall issue a license to each individual covered
by the application within 72 hours of the receipt of a completed application
unless he determines that the application is incorrect in some respect material
to that individual, that the applicant proposes to engage in unlawful activity,
or that he has reason to believe that a clear and present danger to the
residents of the Village would exist through the issuance of a license to a
specific applicant. If the application is to cover more than one individual, a
separate license will be required by each such individual, and may be issued
based on a single application. The filing fee for each license shall be paid
before the license is issued. The license shall bear the photograph of the
individual to whom it is issued and shall not be transferable.
   (e)   The filing fee for licenses shall be as follows:
      (1)   For the initial application and one individual license thereunder,
$1.00;
      (2)   For subsequent licenses issued in connection with an application on
behalf of more than one individual, $1.00 per individual.
   (f)   A peddler shall have his license with him at all times that he is
engaged in peddling within the Village, and shall display it on the request of
any individual from whom he is soliciting.
   (g)   A license shall expire one year from its issuance.
   (h)   No person shall act as a peddler in activities at dwelling houses, at
businesses, or on sidewalks or streets of the Village, between the hours of 9:
00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.
(Ord. 2004-19. Passed 5-3-04.)
729.02 CANVASSERS.
   (a)   “Canvasser,” as used in this chapter, means any person who is at least
eighteen years of age, who goes from house to house or from place to place
through the streets of the Village of Wellington, and who solicits funds
through donations for the benefit of any patriotic, philanthropic, social
service, welfare, eleemosynary, benevolent, educational, charitable, civic,
fraternal, veterans’, social research, political, or religious purpose.
   Notwithstanding the foregoing, a person is not acting as a canvasser under
any of the following circumstances:
      (1)   He is responding to a prior request from the person being
contacted;
      (2)   He is contacting only members of the same entity, group, or
organization on whose behalf he is canvassing;
      (3)   He is making a delivery of goods, wares, food, or merchandise which
has previously been ordered;
      (4)   He is engaged in commercial sales to a commercial business on
behalf of a manufacturer, wholesaler, distributor, or other supplier; or
      (5)   He is simultaneously licensed as a peddler.
   (b)   No person shall either engage in business as a canvasser or, as the
employee of another for such purpose, act as a canvasser within the Village of
Wellington, without having registered with the Village Chief of Police or his
designee.
   (c)   Registration to act as a canvasser shall be filed with the Village
Chief of Police by the individual intending to act as a canvasser or by the
organization he represents, on a form to be furnished by the Chief of Police,
which shall require the following information:
      (1)   Name of the organization for which contributions will be solicited
and one of that organization’s officers;
      (2)   The nature or purpose of the organization;
      (3)   The name, address, and telephone number of the person in charge of
the canvassing activity;
      (4)   The name and address of the person(s) who will be doing the
canvassing;
      (5)   The length of time during which the canvassing will be conducted.
   (d)   The Chief of Police shall issue a certificate to the organization or
individual covered by the registration within 72 hours of the receipt of a
completed application unless he determines that the application is incorrect in
some material respect.
   (e)   A canvasser shall have with him at all times that he is engaged in
canvassing within the Village, and shall display on the request of any
individual from whom he is soliciting, the following:
      (1)   A legible copy of the pertinent certificate of registration; and
      (2)   An identification card, bearing a current photograph of the
individual, and issued by the organization on whose behalf he is canvassing,
identifying the individual as an authorized representative.
   (f)   A license shall expire at the conclusion of the period designated in
the application, or in one year, whichever is sooner.
   (g)   No person shall act as a canvasser in activities at dwelling houses,
at businesses, or on sidewalks or streets of the Village, between the hours of
9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.
(Ord. 2004-19. Passed 5-3-04.)
729.03  APPEALS.
   Any person who has been denied a license or certificate of registration
pursuant to the requirements of this chapter may appeal by submitting a written
notice of appeal to the Village Clerk of Council within five days after
issuance of the denial; in such case, the Council may approve, disapprove, or
modify the Chief of Police’s decision and shall take action with respect to the
appeal within thirty days after filing of the notice with the Clerk of Council;
thereafter, the applicant may appeal according to state law.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
729.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both.
Each day’s continued violation of any provision of this chapter shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2004-19. Passed 5-3-04.)
CHAPTER 745
Temporary Stores
745.01   License required; definition.
745.02   Exceptions.
745.03   Application for license; fees.
745.04   Revocation of license.
745.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.64
 
745.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; DEFINITION.
   No person shall engage in the business of conducting or operating a
temporary store within the Municipality without obtaining a license therefor
from the Director of Finance. "Temporary store" means any place opened for the
sale, bartering or exchange, at auction or otherwise, of goods, wares,
merchandise or other articles of value, within the Municipality for a period
less than 120 days.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
745.02 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to persons selling by sample only, nor to any
agricultural articles or products offered or exposed for sale by the producer
thereof.
(1928 Code Sec. 280.)
745.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEES.
   Application for a license shall be made to the Director of Finance who, upon
being furnished with sufficient proof that the applicant is of good moral
character, shall issue a license and shall charge the following fees therefor:
 
For one day      $ 5.00
For one week       10.00
For one month    15.00
For four months    25.00
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
745.04 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked at
any time should the person to whom it is issued be guilty of any fraud,
misrepresentation or unlawful act in connection with his business, or
otherwise, or is found to be a person not fit to be engaged in such business.
(Ord. 1961-15. Passed 7-3-61.)
745.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree. Each sale or attempted sale, made by any person in violation
of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a distinct and
separate offense.
CHAPTER 749
Alarm Systems
749.01   Prohibition.
749.02   Conformance.
749.03   Disconnection.
749.04   Individual electronic alerting devices permitted.
749.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
False alarm - see GEN. OFF.
509.07
 
749.01 PROHIBITION.
   No person shall erect, install, insert, attach, build, create or otherwise
use any alarm system which by electronic, electric, radio, automatic or
mechanical means on the occurrence of a given event, circumstance or condition
transmits a signal or voice communication for reception by either the
Municipality of Wellington Police Department or the Community Fire District on
their established telephone lines or radio frequencies.
(Ord. 1977-6. Passed 2-7-77.)
749.02 CONFORMANCE.
   (a)   All new fire alarm system specifications shall conform to all state
and local codes. Specifications shall be submitted to the State of Ohio
Buildings and Factories for approval. The system specifications shall also be
presented to the Fire Chief for approval.
   (b)   All new and existing fire alarm systems that will be monitored shall
be monitored by a 24 hour Emergency Response Center (ERC), it is the
responsibility of the facility to contract with an (ERC) at no cost to the
Village of Wellington or the Wellington Community Fire District.
   (c)   Maintenance. The system shall be maintained by the owner of the system
in conformance with all state and local codes. 
(Ord. 2000-61. Passed 1-8-01.)
749.03 DISCONNECTION.
   The receiving unit shall be permitted to remain for only so long as it does
not interfere with the normal daily operation of the Police Dispatch Office.
Upon the determination by Council that such alarm system is not an aid to
preventing crime, the apprehension of criminals, fighting fires or that it is
disrupting or interfering with the daily operation of the Police Dispatch
Office, the alarm monitoring unit shall be disconnected and removed.
(Ord. 1977-6. Passed 2-7-77.)
749.04 INDIVIDUAL ELECTRONIC ALERTING DEVICES PERMITTED.
   (a)   The use of individual electronic alerting devices which are approved
and properly licensed for operation by the Federal Communications Commission,
along with similarly approved sending units or other components used in
conjunction with such alerting devices shall be permitted within the
Municipality as are other alarm systems.
   (b)   In each case the individual, before utilizing the device, shall be
required to notify the Village of Wellington Police Chief and the Wellington
Community Fire District Fire Chief of the proposed use, and the type of alarm
device.
(Ord. 2000-61. Passed 1-8-01.)
749.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 751
Video Service Provider Fee
751.01   Video Service Provider Fee.
751.01 VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE.
   Any video service provider operating within the Village of Wellington shall
pay a 5% video service provider fee on Gross Revenues, which shall include
advertising revenues as part of Gross Revenue. Said fee shall be calculated,
assessed, and paid in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 1332, Ohio
Revised Code, and, specifically, Section 1332.32, as the same may, from time to
time, be amended by the Ohio Legislature.
(Ord. 2014-30. Passed 8-4-14.)
CHAPTER 753
Cable Television Lobbyists
753.01   Definitions.
753.02   General requirements.
753.03   Registration statement.
753.04   Statement of expenditures; records.
753.05   Communications with Council;    Village officials.   
753.06   Ownership structure.
753.07   Filing of statements; copies.
753.08   Investigating; violations.
753.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Having an unlawful interest in a public contract - see GEN. OFF.
525.10
Soliciting or receiving improper compensation - see GEN. OFF.
525.11
 
753.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter, the words and phrases defined in this section
shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them, except where a different
meaning is clearly indicated by the context.
   (a)   "Compensation" means a salary, gift, payment, benefit, subscription,
loan, advance, reimbursement or deposit of money or anything of value or
contract, promise, or agreement, whether or not locally enforceable to make
compensation.
   (b)   "Engage" means any arrangement whereby a person is employed or
retained for compensation to act in some part to influence cable television
franchise legislation or award.
   (c)   "Expenditure" means payment, distribution, loan, advance, deposit,
reimbursement, or gift of money, real estate, or anything of value; or a
contract, promise or agreement, whether or not legally enforceable, to make an
expenditure.
   (d)   "Influence legislation" means to promote, advocate, or oppose the
passage, defeat, or executive approval or veto of cable television franchise
legislation or award by direct communication with any member of Council, the
Mayor, or a member of the Administrative staff of the Municipality.
   (e)   "Legislation" means ordinances, resolutions, amendments and other
matters pending before Council, including executive approval or veto of any
matter acted upon by Council pertaining to a cable television franchise or
award of the same.
   (f)   "Person" or "applicant" means any individual, partnership, trust,
estate, business trust, association, corporation, or entity being a bidder or
prospective bidder for a cable television franchise or having a financial
relationship therein, through employment, stock interest or otherwise.
      (Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.02 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No person engaged to influence cable television franchise legislation
shall fail to register as required under Section
753.03.
 
   (b)   No person engaged to influence cable television franchise legislation
shall fail to keep a receipt or maintain a record as required by Section
753.04.
 
   (c)   No person engaged to influence cable television franchise legislation
shall fail to file a statement as required by Section
753.03.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.03 REGISTRATION STATEMENT.
   (a)   Any person seeking to influence cable television franchise
legislation, directly or through another, shall file with the Director of
Finance a registration statement showing all of the following: (Ord. 2012-13.
Passed 5-7-12.)
      (1)   The person's name, business address and occupation.
      (2)   The name and business address of the person(s) who is (are)
compensating such person to influence the legislation, or a description of the
financial relationship involved.
      (3)   A brief description of the legislation such person is being
compensated to influence.
 
   (b)   Upon a change in any information required by this section, the
registration statement filed pursuant to this section, shall be amended, within
thirty days, to reflect such change.
 
   (c)   No registration statement shall be valid beyond December 31, of each
even-numbered year.
 
   (d)   No registration fee shall be charged.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.04 STATEMENT OF EXPENDITURES; RECORDS.
   (a)   Each person who is compensated to influence cable television franchise
legislation shall file with the Clerk of Council a statement of expenditures.
The statement shall show the total amount of expenditures made by the person
filing the statement to influence such legislation and the specific purpose of
the expenditure. The person shall also state the name of the public body,
public officer or employee to whom or on whose behalf the expenditure was made,
the total amount of the expenditure, and the exact legislation sought to be
influenced, by ordinance or resolution number. The statement shall be filed on
or before the first Tuesday of each month. Each statement shall cover
expenditures made during the preceding month. In cases in which it is
impractical or impossible todetermine exact dollar amounts or values of
expenditures, reporting of good faith estimates, based upon reasonable
accounting procedures, shall constitute compliance with this section.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
 
   (b)   All persons who are compensated to influence cable television
franchise legislation shall retain receipts or maintain records for all
expenditures that are required to be reported pursuant to this section. These
receipts or records shall be maintained for a period ending on the December 31
of the calendar year after the year in which the expenditure was made.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.05 COMMUNICATIONS WITH COUNCIL; VILLAGE OFFICIALS.
   (a)   Communications with Council by applicants, their agents and their
representatives shall be reported at public sessions of Council. Communications
with individual Municipal officials and employees by applicants, their agents
and their representatives is prohibited, except the request for information or
for meetings or for meetings to exchange necessary information should be
addressed to the Mayor or his designee. Council members, the Mayor and other
Municipal officials are required to disclose any discussions held, information
provided or meetings attended other than Council's public sessions with
applicants, their agents and their representatives.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
 
   (b)   The aforesaid disclosure shall be made by filing a written statement
with the Clerk of Council summarizing the discussions held within one week of
the contact or meeting. The statement shall contain the name or names of the
persons contacting the official. The Clerk of Council shall keep those
statements in accordance with Section
753.07.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
 
   (c)   Communication is prohibited by applicant, their agent and their
representatives with the Municipality's cable television consultant.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.06 OWNERSHIP STRUCTURE.
   The ownership structure of the applicant is a matter to be determined by the
applicant, however, this discourages the solicitation and/or use of local
citizens or affiliations for the purpose of influencing the award of a
franchise. If local participation is a component of the ownership structure of
the applicant, then the Municipality desires that such local interest have a
bona fide investment in that company. Local ownership is not a requirement for
receiving the award of the franchise. If an applicant includes participation of
residents of the Municipality in its ownership structure, the Municipality
encourages innovative methods of structuring to maximize that participation. In
reviewing ownership interests, the Municipality will look with disfavor on
proposals containing the following elements.
   (a)   Proposals in which any investor's percentage of stock is greater than
the percentage of total funds or services actually invested. Services
contributed in lieu of monetary investment may include personal services,
materials, equipment or facilities, but such must be quantifiable.
   (b)   Proposals where investors have received loans of assurances of loans
in the future from the cable company with which to purchase stock.
   (c)   Proposals where a cable company guarantees the investors little or no
financial risk.
      (Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
753.07 FILING OF STATEMENTS; COPIES.
   The Clerk of Council shall keep on file the statements required by Sections
753.03 and
753.04. Such statements are public records and open to public inspection. The
Clerk of Council shall provide copies of the statements to the general public
upon request and may charge a reasonable fee not to exceed the cost of copying
and delivering the statement.
(Ord. 2012-13. Passed 5-7-12.)
753.08 INVESTIGATING; VIOLATIONS.
   The Director of Law or his designee may investigate compliance with this
chapter, and in the event of an apparent violation, shall institute such
proceedings as are appropriate.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
753.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   A violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor of
the first degree.
 
   (b)   Council, in its discretion, may eliminate from consideration any
applicant for the award of a cable television franchise within the Municipality
because of a violation or violations of the provisions of this chapter by any
of its members, agents or representatives.
(Ord. 1982-10. Passed 4-5-82.)
CHAPTER 757
Game Rooms
757.01   Permit required.
757.02   Definitions.
757.03   Mechanical requirements.
757.04   Permit procedures and fee.
757.05   Permit revocation.
757.06   Seizure and destruction of gambling device.
757.07   Denial of permit.
757.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machine - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
 
757.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall own or operate a game room as defined
herein within the corporate limits of Wellington without first obtaining a
permit therefor.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter the terms defined in the following
subsections shall have the meaning therein assigned.
   (a)   "Electronic games" includes simulated aerial or space flights, aerial,
terrestial or space battles, road races dexterity or coordination tests or
similar amusement devices operated by the insertion of a coin, disc or other
insertion piece, and which register a score after the insertion of such coin,
disc or other insertion piece.
   (b)   "Game room" includes any place of business containing and displaying
for use therein four or more electronic games or pinball machines or any
combination thereof.
   (c)   "Pinball machine" includes bagatelles, marble machines, table bowling,
table hockey and any similar amusement devices operated by the insertion of a
coin, disc or other insertion piece, and which registers or may register a
score after the insertion of such coin, disc or other insertion piece; it shall
not include coin operated vending machines, music machines or devices used bona
fide and solely for the vending or service of food or merchandise.
      (Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.03 MECHANICAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No permit shall be issued for any pinball machine, electronic game or
similar device which is so constructed as to make possible, either directly, or
by the use of an adjustment, the return of cash, tickets, discs or other
tokens, or certificates of any kind to a player or players operating the
machine game or device whether or not such discs, tokens or certificates have a
value of any kind, or authorize further playing or other privileges.
 
   (b)   Only machines or electronic games or similar devices operated
exclusively for amusement provided by the operation thereof shall be licensed.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.04 PERMIT PROCEDURES AND FEE.
   (a)   Each person, firm or corporation desiring to own, operate or manage a
game room in the Municipality shall first make application for same on forms
provided by the Municipality and shall furnish such data as may be required
which shall include the full name and address of the applicant, and of the
manager or other person in charge, the location for which the permit is sought,
the type and quantity of pinball machines, electronic games or similar
amusement devices to be installed or exhibited and such other information as
may be deemed necessary for the enforcement of this chapter.
 
   (b)   An annual fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall accompany each
application.
 
   (c)   A permit shall be valid for one year from date of its issue and may be
renewed in the manner and for the fee set forth above so long as all other
regulations are met.
 
   (d)   No person, firm or corporation shall fail to display a proper permit
upon proper request therefor.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.05 PERMIT REVOCATION.
   Should the owner, renter, operator, exhibitor or other person, firm or
corporation in possession of a duly licensed pinball machine, electronic game
or other similar amusement device use or permit the same to be used for
gambling purposes or violate the provisions of this chapter the permit for such
operation shall be revoked and the device removed from the premises.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.06 SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF GAMBLING DEVICE.
   Should it be determined after a Court hearing that a pinball machine,
electronic game or similar amusement device has been used for gambling
purposes, machines or devices may be seized along with all other pinball
machines, electronic games and similar amusement devices on the premises in
which such offense occurred and the same should be destroyed forthwith.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.07 DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall be issued a permit for any
pinball machine, electronic game or similar amusement device when it appears
that the applicant has a prior revocation or denial of a permit under this
chapter or if it appears that the premises for which the permit is being sought
have previously been used for purposes in violation of this chapter.
 
   (b)   No permit shall be issued to a person, firm or corporation having a
prior conviction of a felony offense. Should it appear at any time that a
permit already issued was in error due to conflict with the provisions of this
ordinance, the same shall immediately be revoked.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
757.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to all other provisions and remedies of this chapter a person,
firm or corporation found by a court of record to be in violation of the
provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 7-6-81.)
CHAPTER 765
Sidewalk Cafes
765.01   Intent.
765.02   Definitions.
765.03   Permit required.
765.04   Application and permit fees.
765.05   Permit application.
765.06   Location rules and review criteria.
765.07   Conditions of permit.
765.08   Liability and insurance.
765.09   Denial, revocation, or suspension of permit.
765.99   Penalty.
765.01 INTENT.
   The purpose of this chapter is to permit and encourage sidewalk use that is
compatible with other public uses of the public sidewalk. The Village finds
that sidewalk cafes encourage a pedestrian-oriented environment, help to create
a visually attractive atmosphere and promote overall commerce. Regulations and
standards for the existence and operation of sidewalk cafes are necessary to
facilitate and ensure a safe environment in these areas. The issuance of a
sidewalk cafe permit shall not constitute nor shall it be construed to
constitute a vacation or abandonment by the Village of its interest in the
right-of-way or any easements contained therein.    
(Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
765.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Abutting property owners and occupants" means any owner or occupant
of property which abuts the subject sidewalk cafe site excluding public right-
of-way.
   (b)    "Adjacent sidewalk area" means that portion of the public sidewalk
between the curb line and the property line demarcated by extending the side
building lines of the premises until they intersect the curb.
   (c) "Sidewalk Café" means:
      (1)   A place serving food or beverage from a restaurant or other retail
establishments with ancillary food service to patrons seated at tables located
within the adjacent sidewalk area or providing seating for patrons in the
adjacent sidewalk area.
      (2)   An abutting property owner or occupant conducting business within a
building and desiring to temporarily display items for sale and/or a temporary
sign (including sandwich board signs) within the adjacent sidewalk area
relating to the business.
         (Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
765.0 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Private commercial use of public sidewalks for the purpose of operating a
Sidewalk Cafe in the Village is prohibited unless a permit is obtained from the
Manager as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
765.04 APPLICATION AND PERMIT FEES.
   The initial application and annual permit fee shall be five dollars ($5.00)
if the proposed installation is limited to a single sign only, but will be
twenty dollars ($20.00) for all other permits; the fee is due at the time of
the initial application (provided that a credit shall be given for the initial
five dollar ($5.00) fee in the event a single sign permit is being replaced by
a larger installation). No application fee shall be required for renewals.
(Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
765.05 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Application for a permit to operate a sidewalk cafe shall be made to the
Manager on a form provided. The request for permit shall contain:
   (a)    A completed application;
   (b)    A fully dimensioned scale site plan of the area for the proposed
sidewalk cafe;
     (c)    A certificate of insurance and endorsement form; and
   (d)    The location and description of any tables, materials, merchandise,
sign or equipment requested to be in the right-of-way.
   (e)    Other information shall be provided as required by the Manager or
Police Chief to carry out the purpose of this chapter.
      (Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
765.06 LOCATION RULES AND REVIEW CRITERIA.
   The Administrator shall review the application for its compliance with the
following criteria:
   (a)    The operation of a sidewalk cafe is limited to structures which are
sited within ten feet of a public sidewalk, and which are located in the
Downtown Business Districts.
   (b)    The operation of a sidewalk cafe shall be located such that there is
at least five feet clear and unobstructed passageway between any tables,
merchandise, materials sign, or equipment and street trees, bike racks, lamp
posts, sign posts, and any other fixtures or obstructions. Building entrances
or exits shall not be obstructed. The Administrator may require more than five
feet if necessary to protect the public safety.
   (c)    The sidewalk cafe may only be located in the adjacent sidewalk area
to a permitted use, but may extend in front of adjacent businesses with the
written consent of both the property owner and the business owner, subject to
review and approval of the Administrator.
   (d)    The sidewalk cafe tables, merchandise, materials, sign, or equipment
shall be located five feet from driveways and alleys, and ten feet from
intersections.
   (e)   No more than a single sidewalk sign may be used in connection with
each permit. The face of a sidewalk sign shall not exceed twelve (12) square
feet.
   (f)    The location of the sidewalk cafe shall be as approved by the
Administrator. Sidewalk signs shall normally be approved for placement either
one foot from the building or one foot from the curb to promote the safe
progress of sidewalk traffic.
   (g)    The Administrator shall forward all applications for review by the
Police Chief.
      (Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
765.07 CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
   All sidewalk cafe permit holders shall be subject to the following;
   (a)    Each permit issued shall be valid from April 1 through December 1 of
the year in which it is issued. Requests for renewals shall be filed with the
Manager after the first day of January. The Manger may approve, approve with
additional conditions, or deny the request for renewal.
   (b)    The permit issued shall be valid only for the permittee and is not
transferable in any manner.
   (c)    The permit may be temporarily suspended by the Manager if the public
interest requires use of the right-of-way for a public event, construction,
repair, or any other public purpose.
   (d)    The permit is specifically limited to the area approved or as
modified by the Manager, and will include a diagram indicating the area
approved for the sidewalk cafe and the location of any tables, materials,
merchandise, sign, or equipment permitted to be in the right-of-way.
   (e)    The sidewalk and all things placed there shall at all times be
maintained in a clean and orderly condition. Only those items authorized by the
permit and shown on the diagram may be stored in the public right-of-way when
the sidewalk cafe is not in operation. Should the permittee not utilize the
sidewalk as authorized for a period of 48 hours or more, all the tables,
merchandise, equipment, sign and materials shall be removed therefrom.
   (f)    The permittee shall clear any litter from the public sidewalk in the
area of operation of a sidewalk cafe at the close of business and provide
additional trash containers as specified by the Manager.
   (g)    No signs shall be attached to any furniture, umbrellas, awnings, or
other structure related to the operation of the sidewalk cafe.
   (h)    Sidewalk cafes shall be continuously supervised by employees of the
establishment and may be occupied only during the hours of operation of the
establishment.
   (i)   Sidewalk cafes shall meet all requirements of the County Health
Department.
   (j)    Tables, chairs, merchandise, equipment, and other materials
associated with the sidewalk cafe shall be kept free of litter and other debris
at all times. Where establishments provide take-out or selfservice, an adequate
number of employees must be maintained to clear sidewalk cafes on a regular
basis. Sidewalk and flooring areas must be cleaned daily, including adjacent
sidewalk areas.
   (k)    The Village has the right to repeal or amend this chapter and thereby
terminate or modify all sidewalk cafe operations. No permittee shall obtain any
property right in the continued private commercial use of the public sidewalk.
   (l)    Businesses shall not serve or permit the consumption of alcoholic
beverages within the public sidewalk or right of way under any circumstances.
      (Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
765.08 LIABILITY AND INSURANCE.
   Prior to the issuance of permit, permittee shall:
   (a)    Furnish a signed statement, with the application, that the permittee
shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the Village, its officers and
employees, from any and all claims for damages to property or injury to persons
which may occur in connection with any activity carried on under the terms of
the permit.
   (b) Each sidewalk cafe permit holder shall provide proof of liability
insurance in the form of a certificate of insurance with limits no less than
five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) per occurrence, one million dollars
($1,000,000) aggregate and the Village of Wellington must be named on the
certificate as additionally insured as a condition of the permit.
      (Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
765.09 DENIAL, REVOCATION, OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT.
   The Manager may deny, revoke, or suspend the permit upon finding that any
provision of this chapter or condition of approval has been violated. Upon
denial, revocation, or suspension, the Manager shall give notice of such action
to the applicant or permittee in writing stating the action that has been taken
and the reason therefor. The action shall be effective immediately.
(Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09; Ord. 2010-45. Passed 12-20-10.)
765.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Each day such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2009-10. Passed 4-20-09.)
CHAPTER 767
Business Refuse
767.01   Garbage and rubbish disposal.
767.99   Penalty.
767.01 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH DISPOSAL.
   (a)   Every operator of a business within the Village shall dispose of all
of the rubbish generated by the business in a clean and sanitary manner by
placing it in approved receptacles or in other approved rubbish disposal
facilities.
   (b)   Every operator of a business within the Village shall disposal of all
garbage generated by the business and any other organic waste which might
provide food for insects and rodents in a clean and sanitary manner by placing
it in approved, nonleakable, nonabsorbent, covered garbage storage receptacles
or in other approved garbage disposal facilities.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of every operator of a business within the
Village to provide, or cause to be provided, and at all times thereafter to
keep or cause to be kept and provided for the exclusive use of such business,
receptacles with close-fitting covers for receiving and holding without
leakage, all garbage and rubbish, so long as such garbage and rubbish remains
upon or in such building, premises or places of business.
      (1)   Such receptacles shall be regularly located and maintained upon
private property only.
      (2)   Where necessary, such receptacles may be permitted to be
temporarily placed upon a public sidewalk and/or within the public right-of-
way, in a manner which does not obstruct pedestrian or vehicle traffic, in
anticipation of pick-up for permanent disposal of the refuse. Placement/storage
of such receptacles upon a public sidewalk and/or within the public right-of-
way shall only be between sunset of the day prior to expected pick-up and
sunset of the day of pick-up; placement/storage of such receptacles upon a
public sidewalk and/or within the public right-of-way at any other times is
prohibited.
   (d)   It shall be the duty of every operator of a business within the
Village to make the necessary arrangements for the pickup and removal of
rubbish and garbage so as not to overload the containers or receptacles.
   (e)   Every operator of a business within the Village shall maintain the
outside premises free from all trash, wastes and garbage unless deposited into
an approved waste container.
   (f)   No operator of a business within the Village shall place, or cause to
be placed, any garbage or refuse generated by the business in a public waste
receptacle owned or placed by the Village or in a receptacle owned or placed by
another business operator.
   (g)   No person shall tamper with, interfere with, carry away, damage, or
destroy any garbage or refuse receptacles owned by the Village or another
person.
   (h)   The public is encouraged to use public waste disposal receptacles on
the public streets and sidewalks in the Village for immediate disposal of small
items normally discarded by pedestrians and passing motorists while they are in
transit. Nothing in this section prohibits a business operator from placing
such receptacles for public use upon a sidewalk and/or public right- of-way,
provided that:
      (1)   Such receptacles are regularly emptied at least as often as the
business’s regular refuse collection;
      (2)   Such receptacles do not obstruct pedestrian or vehicle traffic; and
      (3)   Such receptacles are not used by the business for the deposit of
garbage or refuse generated by the business.
         (Ord. 2009-55. Passed 1-19-10.)
767.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2009-55. Passed 1-19-10.)
CHAPTER 769
Sweepstakes/Internet Cafes
769.01   Title; purpose; objectives.
769.02   Construction; severability.
769.03   Definitions.
769.04   Computerized sweepstakes device license required.
769.05   Sweepstakes/Internet Café license required.
769.06   Nature of licenses.
769.07   Procedures for obtaining licenses.
769.08   License conditions; denial/revocation of licenses.
769.09   License fees.
769.99   Penalty.
769.01 TITLE; PURPOSE; OBJECTIVES.
   (a)   Title. This Chapter shall be known as the “Sweepstakes/Internet Café”
Ordinance.
   (b)   Purpose and Objectives. It is the purpose of this Chapter and the
policy of the Village of Wellington to establish standards for licensing and
regulation of computerized sweepstakes intended devices and/or internet cafes
within which they are located and operated. This Chapter is intended to prevent
safety and fire hazards, prevent disturbances, preserve the peaceful enjoyment
of neighboring establishments and residences, and prevent gambling, truancy,
and other criminal behavior in the Village.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.02 CONSTRUCTION; SEVERABILITY.
   (a)   Construction. This Chapter shall be liberally construed and applied to
promote its purpose and objectives.
   (b)   Severability. If any provision of this Chapter, or the application
thereof to any person, or circumstance, is held invalid or unconstitutional by
any court of competent jurisdiction, such provision shall be deemed a separate,
distinct, and independent provision; and neither the remainder of this Chapter,
nor the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances shall
be affected thereby. (Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   (a)   “Computerized Sweepstakes Device” means any computer, machine, game or
apparatus which, upon the insertion of a coin, token, access number, code,
magnetic card, or similar object, or upon the payment or exchange of anything
of value, provides a product or service, which may be operated by the public
generally for use as a contest of skill, entertainment or amusement, whether or
not registering a score, and which provides the user with a chance to win
anything of value that is not de minimus, provided, however, that machines
designated for use by the State Lottery Commission are not Computerized
Sweepstakes Devices for purposes of this Section.
   (b)   “Operator” means any person or persons having authority to control the
premises of a Sweepstakes/Internet Café.
   (c)   “Licensee” means the person or persons who sign an application for a
license hereunder and to whom such license is issued.
   (d)   “Owner” means any person who possesses a pecuniary interest, either
directly or indirectly, of twenty-five percent (25%) or more in a Sweepstakes/
Internet Café.
   (e)   “Sweepstakes/Internet Café” means any premises upon which any
Computerized Sweepstakes Device is located for the use or entertainment of the
public, whether or not such premises have other business purposes of any nature
whatsoever.
      (Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.04 COMPUTERIZED SWEEPSTAKES DEVICE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall display for purpose of use within the Village any
Computerized Sweepstakes Device without first having obtained a license
therefor as provided in this Chapter, which license shall be designated as a
Computerized Sweepstakes Device License. A separate license shall be required
for each such Computerized Sweepstakes Device.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.05 SWEEPSTAKES/INTERNET CAFE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate or
conduct a sweepstakes/internet café without first obtaining a license therefor
as provided in this Chapter, which license shall be designated as a
Sweepstakes/Internet Café License.
   (b)   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate or
conduct a Sweepstakes/Internet Café at any time unless the information on file
with the Village is current and accurately reports the licensing information at
the time of operation.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.06 NATURE OF LICENSES.
   (a)   Each license issued under this Chapter shall be in effect for a period
of twelve months and shall expire on the anniversary of its issuance , unless
renewed for a successive twelve months or unless earlier suspended or revoked.
   (b)   Each license issued under this Chapter shall be a personal privilege
and shall not vest a property right.
   (c)   Each license issued under this Chapter shall be prominently displayed
in a conspicuous place at the site for which it is issued and shall be open to
public inspection.
   (d)   Each license issued under this Chapter shall be issued in the name of
the applicant.
   (e)   A license issued under this Chapter shall not be assignable or
transferable, either as to person, business, entity, or location.
   (f)   Licenses for Computerized Sweepstakes Devices shall comply with these
requirements:
      (1)   One license shall be issued for each Device.
      (2)   Each license shall specify: name and address of the licensee, name
of the manufacturer, model number and serial number of the Device for which it
is issued.
      (3)   A license shall be invalid if the Device is moved to a new
location.
      (4)   A license shall be invalid if changed, mutilated, erased, or in any
manner defaced.
   (g)   Licenses for Sweepstakes/Internet Cafes shall comply with these
requirements:
      (1)   One license shall be issued for an individual business at an
individual premises.
      (2)   Each license shall specify name and address of the licensee, and
the manufacture, model number, and serial number of each Computerized
Sweepstakes Device located on the premises for which the license is issued.
      (3)   A license shall be invalid if changed, mutilated, erased, or in any
manner defaced.
      (4)   The person, partnership, corporation, or other entity operating or
conducting the business shall have a continuing duty to inform the Village as
to changes in the information required in the application for license.
         (Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.07  PROCEDURES FOR OBTAINING LICENSES.
   (a)   Applications for Licenses. All applications for licenses under this
Chapter shall be in writing on a form approved by and filed with the Village
Manager, or his designee. The application shall be signed by the owner(s) of
the business and shall contain the information required by this Chapter. All
applications shall contain a statement that the information contained therein
is complete, accurate, and truthful to the best of the knowledge of the
applicants.
   (b)   Contents of Applications.  
      (1)   All applications shall contain the following information:
         A.   The name under which the business is to be conducted;
         B.   A description of the nature and type of business to be conducted
on the premises.
      (2)   All applications for a license to operate a Sweepstakes/Internet
Café shall, in addition to the information set forth in subsection (b)(1)
above, contain the following information:
         A.   The location where the café is conducted, with a description of
the premises;
         B.   The telephone number of the café;
         C.   The name, address, date of birth, and principal occupation of
every person with an interest in the business;
            1.   If the business is conducted by a sole proprietorship: the
name, home address, date of birth and principal occupation of that individual;
            2.   If the business is conducted by partnership: the names, home
addresses, dates of birth, and principal occupations of each member of the
partnership;
            3.   If the business is conducted by a corporation: the names, home
addresses, dates of birth and principal occupations of all directors, all
officers, and the statutory agent;
         D.   The name, description, model number and serial number of each
Computerized Sweepstakes Device on the premises of the Café;
         E.   A floor plan of the Premises, including the square footage of the
area to be used for the placement of Computerized Sweepstakes Devices, exit
locations, window locations, window sizes, and storage spaces;
         F.   A diagram showing the premises and any adjoining businesses, as
well as parking spaces drawn to scale, and accessways for traffic;
         G.   A description of the days of the week and hours when the Café
will be open for business;
         H.   A list of each separate prize that may be given out and each
separate dollar amount that may be given; and the odds of winning any offered
prize or dollar amount awarded for the participation in any game, activity,
program, scheme or play, use or participation in any way in a Computerized
Sweepstakes Device or participation in any other activity or promotion in the
Sweepstakes/Internet Café, whether or not the determination of the giving of
the thing of value or the delivery of the thing of value occurs totally within
the confines of the premises or requires some event, occurrence or happening at
another location.
         I.   The name and business address of any and all persons, businesses
or organizations that provide games, computer software, equipment, or services
or operate devices linked to the computerized sweepstakes devices or to devices
necessary to operate the entertainment devices, whether any such provisions are
sold, leased or licensed.
      (3)   All applications for a license to operate a Computerized
Sweepstakes Device shall, in addition to the information set forth in
subsection (b)(1) above, contain the following information:
         A.   The location where the Device is to be installed;
         B.   The name, address, and date of birth of the owner or owners of
the Device;
            1.   If owner is a sole proprietorship: the name, home address, and
date of birth of that individual.
            2.   If the owner is a partnership: the names, home addresses, and
dates of birth, of each member of the partnership.
            3.   If the owner is a corporation: the names, home addresses,
dates of birth and principal occupations of all directors, all officers, and
the statutory agent.
         C.   The name, description, model number and serial number of each
Computerized Sweepstakes Device
   The application shall also include supporting documentation from a Certified
Independent Regulatory Compliance Test Laboratory that the software performs in
similar fashion as other permitted sweepstakes commercially offered to the
public and that the entries are drawn from a pre-created finite static pool of
entries with assigned values. To be certified, the Independent Regulatory
Compliance Testing Laboratory must be authorized to test regulated gaming
equipment by at least one state government gaming regulatory agency.
   (c)   Applications shall be submitted to the Village Manager, or his
designee. An application which appears to be complete and in compliance with
the requirements set forth in this Chapter shall be approved within ten (10)
business days of its filing. An application which is either incomplete or which
does not appear to be in compliance with the requirements set forth in this
Chapter may be denied within ten (10) business days of the application’s
filing; in that event, the applicant shall be advised in writing as to the
reasons. The approval of a license under this Chapter shall not exempt the
applicant from compliance with any other provisions of the Codified Ordinances
which may otherwise be applicable.
   (d)   An applicant who has been denied a license under this Chapter may
appeal to the Mayor by submitting a written appeal, together with the reasons
for any appeal, to the Mayor within ten (10) business days after the decision
of the Manager has been issued. In such case, the Mayor shall conduct a hearing
and shall render a decision on the appeal within thirty (30) days after the
appeal has been requested by the applicant.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.08 LICENSE CONDITIONS; DENIAL/REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   (a)   Any license issued under the provisions of this Chapter may be denied,
or the same may be revoked, under any of the following conditions:
      (1)   Failure to pay all fees accruing under this Chapter.
      (2)   Making a false statement of a material fact in the application.
      (3)   Failure to abide the requirements set forth in this Chapter.
   (b)   Any person operating, or proposing to operate, a Computerized
Sweepstakes Device and/or Sweepstakes/Internet Cafe shall comply with the
following provisions; and a license may be denied or revoked for failure to
comply with the following provisions:
      (1)   Computerized Sweepstakes Device shall not be operated within a Use
District which is zoned “Residential” under any circumstances.
      (2)   A Sweepstakes/Internet Café shall be unlocked and shall be open to
inspection and viewing of operations by law enforcement officers and fire
department personnel at all times of operation.
      (3)   A Sweepstakes/Internet Café shall provide at least 30 gross square
feet of floor area for each Computerized Sweepstakes Device, excluding areas
used for other principal uses.
      (4)   A Sweepstakes/Internet Café shall have present on the premises at
all times when the premises are open for business at least one adult operator.
      (5)   Gambling in any form, or the possession or use of gambling
paraphernalia upon the premises is prohibited.
      (6)   The use of alcoholic beverages or unlawful controlled substances
upon the premises is prohibited.
      (7)   Public streets, sidewalks, alleys, or walkways adjacent to the
premises shall not be blocked or littered by patrons of a Sweepstakes/Internet
Café.
      (8)   No minor person shall be allowed within a Sweepstakes/Internet
Café.
      (9)   Any and all sweepstakes rules and the odds of winning shall be
conspicuously posted at all times at each Computerized Sweepstakes Device.
      (10)   Smoking is prohibited at all Sweepstakes/Internet Cafes.
      (11)   All Computerized Sweepstakes Devices shall be installed in
accordance with the plan submitted to the Village; and unimpeded ingress and
egress to the premises shall at all times be maintained.
   (c)   In the event that the Village Manager deems there to be grounds to
consider revocation of a License under this Chapter, the Manager shall provide
at least ten (10) days notice to the Licensee of the proposed action, the
reasons therefor, and of the date for a hearing thereon. If the Manager
determines to revoke the License, the Manager shall provide the Licensee with a
written explanation of the reasons therefor.
   (d)   A Licensee who may appeal to the Mayor from a revocation ordered by
the Manager by submitting a written appeal, together with the reasons for any
appeal, to the Mayor within ten (10) business days after the decision of the
Manager has been issued. In such case, the Mayor shall conduct a hearing and
shall render a decision on the appeal within thirty (30) days after the appeal
has been requested by the applicant.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.09 LICENSE FEES.
   (a)   An initial annual license fee, payable to the Village at the time of
application, shall be Six Thousand Dollars ($6,000) for each Sweepstakes/
Internet Café license. One-half the initial annual fee shall be refunded in the
event that an application is denied; but there shall be no refund if a
Sweepstakes/Internet Café License is revoked.
   (b)   A renewal annual license fee, payable to the Village at the time of
each annual renewal thereafter, shall be Three Thousand Dollars ($3,000) for
each Sweepstakes/Internet Café license. This fee shall not be pro-rated for
partial years. One-half the renewal annual fee shall be refunded in the event
that an application is denied; but there shall be no refund if a Sweepstakes/
Internet Café License is revoked.
   (c)   A nonrefundable fee of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) per device, per month,
shall be payable to the Village each month for each Computerized Sweepstakes
Device License. The license fee shall be paid for each Device brought to the
facility before the device is put into use. For purposes of determining
licensing fees, each Device that is operable by one or more persons is a
separate device.
(Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
769.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2011-09. Passed 4-18-11.)
CHAPTER 777
Mobile Food Vendors
777.01   Intent.
777.02   Definitions.
777.03   Permit required.
777.04   Application and permit fees.
777.05   Permit application.
777.06   Location rules and review criteria for mobile food establishments.
777.07   Conditions of permit.
777.08   Liability and insurance.
777.09   Denial, revocation or suspension of permit.
777.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
Parking generally - see TRAF. Ch.
351
777.01 INTENT.
   The purpose of this chapter is to permit and encourage sidewalk use that is
compatible with other public uses of the public sidewalk and rights-of-way. The
Village recognizes and supports the vitality and activity that may be generated
by the operation of mobile food vendors within the Village, but also recognizes
that careful consideration must be exercised both to prevent the obstruction of
pedestrian, bicycle, and motor vehicle traffic, and to assure that reasonable
levels of safe and sanitary operations are carried out. The issuance of a
permit pursuant to this chapter shall not constitute nor shall it be construed
to constitute a vacation or abandonment by the Village of its interest in the
right-of-way or any easements contained therein.
(Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Mobile food establishment" shall mean a business operation that
provides food for human consumption from a vehicle.
   (b)   “Mobile food vendor" shall mean a person or business entity who
operates a mobile food establishment that is incorporated in or propelled by a
vehicle. A mobile food vendor does not include "meals on wheels," ice cream
trucks or the home delivery of food.
      (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.03 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, organization, or business entity shall operate within the Village
as a mobile food vendor without first having been issued a permit from the
Manager authorizing such operation. An organization which qualifies as a tax-
exempt charitable institution pursuant to subsection 501(c) of the Internal
Revenue Code, which organization intends to directly operate a mobile food
establishment through its own volunteers or employees only shall not be
required to obtain a mobile food vendor permit, or to otherwise comply with the
provisions of this chapter pertaining to mobile food vendors. (Ord. 2018-32.
Passed 9-17-18.)
777.04 APPLICATION AND PERMIT FEES.
   (a)   An applicant to operate as a mobile food vendor may apply for a
single-event permit, for an event not to exceed three (3) consecutive days, for
a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per event, or a permit for more than a single
event, which will expire at the end of each calendar year, for a fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (b)   Permit application fees are non-refundable once submitted, regardless
of whether a permit is issued or denied. (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
   
777.05  PERMIT APPLICATION.
   The application to operate as a mobile food vendor shall be made to the
Manager on a form provided. The request for permit shall contain:
   (a)   A completed application, showing the name, address and telephone
number of the person/entity who will own and/or operate a mobile food
establishment;
   (b)   A description of the food cart, food truck or other vending device
from which the applicant intends to vend, including the dimensions of the cart,
truck or device;
   (c)   A description of the proposed operation of the mobile food
establishment, including a plan illustrating the proposed location(s) of the
operation of the mobile food establishment, proposed operating hours, and
identifying the location of all buildings, parking and loading areas, streets
and driveway approaches, open spaces, refuse and service areas, utilities,
signs, landscaping in the vicinity;
   (d)   A photograph of any mobile food vendor vehicle/unit to be used in
operation of the business;
   (e)   A certificate of insurance and endorsement form;
   (f)   Certification that the mobile food establishment has passed any
inspections required by the Lorain County General Health District.
   (g)   Other information shall be provided as required by the Manager or
Police Chief to carry out the purpose of this chapter.
      (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.06 LOCATION RULES AND REVIEW CRITERIA FOR MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS.
   The Manager shall review the application for its compliance with the
following criteria:
   (a)   (1)   The preferred location for a mobile food establishment is on
privately-owned, non-residential property. The applicant will identify such
location, its owner, and will provide written consent of the owner to the
application. The use of any such location must be consistent with the
applicable zoning for the property. The Manager will not approve an application
where operation of the mobile food vendor will significantly obstruct a public
way, impair the movement of pedestrians or vehicles, impair the clear view of
traffic, or pose any other hazard to public safety.
      (2)   An applicant may request permission to:
         A.   Temporarily operate a food cart which is not independently
capable of movement on a public sidewalk within the Downtown Business District.
Any proposed location where the presence of a food cart on the sidewalk must be
compatible with the public interest in use of sidewalk areas as public right-
of- way; and the Manager may consider the width of the sidewalk; the proximity
and location of existing street installations, including but not limited to
signposts, lamp posts, parking meters, bus shelters, benches, bike racks, and
newspaper vending devices; the presence of bus stops, truck loading zones, and
fire exits or fire escapes; pedestrian and vehicular traffic patterns; and
other factors he or she deems relevant. No permitted location shall be within
ten (10) feet of another permitted location. No permitted location shall be
designated where the clear, continuous, unobstructed sidewalk for the
passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than six (6) feet.
         B.   Temporarily locate the mobile food establishment within right-of-
way areas within the Downtown Business District where vehicles may otherwise
lawfully park. However, all street parking by the vendor shall remain subject
to all applicable restrictions within the Codified Ordinances of Wellington,
including but not limited to the following:
351.03 (prohibited standing or parking places.);
351.04 (parking near curb; handicapped locations on public and private lots and
garages.);
 351.05 (manner of angle parking.);
351.09 (truck loading zones.);
351.11 (parking in alleys and narrow streets; exceptions.);
351.16 (prohibitions in Business District.); and
351.18 (Downtown Parking District regulations.). In consultation with the Chief
of Police, the Manager shall determine whether a proposed location is
compatible with the public interest in using the right-of-way, considering such
factors as the width of the right-of-way, available parking, traffic, pavement
durability, and the times of operation; and will not approve an application
where the operation of the mobile food vendor will significantly obstruct a
public way, impair the movement of pedestrians or vehicles, impair the clear
view of traffic, or pose any other hazard to public safety. Any such approval
for a location within the right-of-way shall be subject to change or revocation
when necessitated by public safety requirements.
   (b)   No mobile food vendor shall provide any dining area, tables, chairs,
booths, bar stools, benches, or standup counters, unless a proposal for such
seating/standup arrangements has submitted with the permit application and
approved by the Manager.
(Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.07 CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
   All mobile food establishment permit holders shall be subject to the
following:
   (a)   Each permit issued shall be valid for either the three-day period for
which applied/approved (for single event permits) or from the approval date
through December 31 of the year in which it is issued.
   (b)   The permit issued shall be valid only for the permittee and is not
transferable in any manner.
   (c)   The permit may be temporarily suspended by the Manager if the right-
of-way is being used and the public interest requires use of the right-of-way
for a public event, construction, repair, or any other public purpose. In the
event of such a suspension, the Manager shall have the discretion to grant a
proportional extension of the permit time or a proportional refund of the
permit fee, as appropriate.
   (d)   The permit is specifically limited to the area approved (or as
modified by the Manager), and will include a diagram indicating the area
approved for the sidewalk cafe and the location of any tables, materials,
merchandise, sign, or equipment permitted to be in the right-of-way.    
   (e)   The sidewalk and all things placed there shall at all times be
maintained in a clean and orderly condition. The mobile food establishment
shall provide and maintain a container suitable for the placement of litter,
which litter shall be removed by the vendor at the close of the business day
and properly disposed of by the vendor.
   (f)   No food cart or related equipment of the operation shall remain within
the sidewalk or right-of-way at any time that the mobile food establishment is
not in operation.
   (g)   Each mobile food establishment shall be continuously supervised by
employees of the establishment.
   (h)   Each mobile food establishment shall continuously meet all applicable
requirements of the Lorain County Health Department.
   (i)   A mobile food establishment shall operate only within the hours for
which it has been approved.
   (j)   Each mobile food establishment shall maintain a legible copy of its
approved permit on-site during all hours of operation; and the same shall be
disclosed to any law enforcement officer upon request.
   (k)   The Village has the right to repeal or amend this chapter and thereby
terminate or modify all sidewalk cafe operations. No permittee shall obtain any
property right in the continued private commercial use of the public sidewalk.
   (l)   Businesses shall not serve or permit the consumption of alcoholic
beverages within the public sidewalk or right of way under any circumstances.
      (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.08  LIABILITY AND INSURANCE.
   Prior to the issuance of permit, permittee shall:
   (a)   Furnish a signed statement, with the application, that the permittee
shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the Village, its officers and
employees, from any and all claims for damages to property or injury to persons
which may occur in connection with any activity carried on under the terms of
the permit.
   (b)   Each mobile food vendor requesting/approved to operate anywhere within
the right-of-way shall provide proof of liability insurance in the form of a
certificate of insurance with limits no less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000) per occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000) aggregate and the
Village of Wellington must be named on the certificate as additionally insured
as a condition of the permit. (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.09  DENIAL, REVOCATION, OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT.
   (a)   The Manager may deny, revoke, or suspend the permit upon finding that
any provision of this chapter or condition of approval has been violated. Upon
denial, revocation, or suspension, the Manager shall give notice of such action
to the applicant or permittee in writing stating the action that has been taken
and the reason therefor. The action shall be effective immediately.
   (b)   An applicant/permit holder who has been so affected may appeal by
submitting a written notice of appeal to the Village Clerk of Council within
five days after issuance of the Manager's action being appealed; in such case,
the Council may approve, disapprove, or modify the Manager's decision and shall
take action with respect to the appeal within thirty days after filing of the
notice with the Clerk of Council; thereafter, the applicant may appeal
according to state law. (Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)
777.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Each day such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2018-32. Passed 9-17-18.)

CHAPTER 911
Excavations
911.01   Permit required.
911.02   Application; deposit and fee.
911.03   Completion of work; forfeit of deposit.
911.04   Barricades.
